text: there are manifestations that I consider
very regrettable of sort of tribalist um
thinking um in religious groups in uh uh
political groups uh there was a great
deal of overlap in these categories of
course and and um increasingly in the
way that people identify themselves um
socioeconomically and then of course
there's always the old problem of race
which is you know has
been uh capitalized on recently in very
very regrettable ways I think that uh
tribalism uh is the presumptive uh in
effect contempt for people that you
identify yourself in contrast to you
know um I I listen with amazement to
people talking about liberal professors
in big secular universities you know and
I'm a liberal professor in a big secular
University and I can promise I have
never tried to indoctrinate anyone I
have no intention to overthrow the
United States of America you know but
you hear these incredibly aggressive and
hostile characterizations made of people
as groups and that's a very very very
dangerous thing to
do I think one of the things that's very
nice about this country historically and
then you know is perhaps more Western
the northeastern is that um people
identify by Affinity that rather than by
an a received identity you know um the
idea that
uh you know I'm from a certain region
therefore I have to believe in a certain
politics and I have to follow a certain
religion and all this sort of thing or
no religion depending um that that takes
individual preference and choice and
Affinity out of you know out of
individual experience and behavior and I
think that's a huge impoverishment of
people uh that they feel that they have
to fall into these loyalties rather than
looking around the landscape and seeing
where they can add something you know
see find where people are doing
something interesting that interests
them also um and it's um you know I I
think that people can cohere very very
well around and much more happily around
Affinity than than around these you know
hard identifications that you receive
passively
